fields.description:
[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/quot-Mergetool-path-issue-quot-when-launching-external-merge/qaq-p/1781360]

OSX / Ver 4.1.3

When I choose "Launch external merge tool" I get
{quote}*Mergetool path issue*

Current path:/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools

Please set the command tool path in Xcode and Try again!
{quote}
I don't know what this means or how to fix

External diff tool works fine

I have Sourcetree 4.1.3

I tried 

{{sudo rm -rf /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools}}

 Sourcetree immediately prompted me to instal Xcode.  Which I did.

Still get the error

*Reverting to Sourcetree 4.1.1  solved issue*
fields.summary: "Mergetool path issue" when launching external merge tool

fields.description:
Incorrectly Cannot See History of NextJS Files w Square Brackets in Folder Path

 

NextJS has a feature called [“*Pages with Dynamic Routes*”|https://nextjs.org/docs/basic-features/pages#pages-with-dynamic-routes], where files named `pages/posts/[id].js`, will be accessible at `posts/1`, `posts/2`, etc.

In SourceTree on Mac, when I attempt to the view the history (e.g. Log Selected…” menu item), then SourceTree presents a modal that says, _“Potential security issue detected in the specified URL.”_ Thus, preventing me to see the history of the such files.

This is a bug, that doesn’t allow me to easily see history for files with dynamic routes in NextJS.

 

*Expected:* No modal error message is presented, and history is shown as normal.

*Actual:* An error modal is presented to the user, thus user cannot see history of the file.

 

!image-2021-08-13-15-01-32-781.png!
fields.summary: Incorrectly Cannot See History of NextJS Files

fields.description:
Hello,

i've been trying to make a pull request using the app but i have found out that it opens the pull request url without encoding it (i have tried this only with azure dev ops)

example :

[https://<repoName>/pullrequestcreate?sourceRef=features/1616/2002-branchFolder1/branchFolder2/branchName|https://dev.azure.com/naxxumgroup/FertiPro/_git/Merck.FertiPro/pullrequest/504]

it should be like that to work :

[https://<repoName>/pullrequestcreate?sourceRef=features/1616/2002-branchFolder1%2FbranchFolder2%2FbranchName|https://dev.azure.com/naxxumgroup/FertiPro/_git/Merck.FertiPro/pullrequest/504]
fields.summary: Pull request url encoding issue (nested branch name)

fields.description:
In my company every single module is it's own repository.  For some projects 4-8 repositories together are a single 'project'.

It would be a very usefull feature to be able to group them and then open the entire group in sourcetree, or close the entire group all at once.

Also a multi-repository Fetch would make life a lot easier to check the status of alle repositories in the group at once.
I imagine this grouping just like the folders in de local-repositories-tab. All repo's in one (group-)folder are that particular group.
Right-click the folder and you can open or close all repo's in that folder at once.
A Fetch-all could also be in the right click menu on that folder .
fields.summary: Group Repositories for grouped action: Open, Close and Fetch

fields.description:
The current (4.1.2) version of Sourcetree crashes constantly on my machine. The crash reports all look identical, so this should be trivial to fix. The cause of the crash is:

Crashing on exception: *** -[__NSArrayM objectAtIndexedSubscript:]: index 0 beyond bounds for empty array

You will find a sample crash report [at this link|[http://hairer.org/Sourcetree.crash]].

fields.description:
This is difficult to explain without screenshots, and I can't find a way to add them in this bug reporter. Please let me know if there is in fact a way to do so.

The "pending files" pane at bottom, left of center, no longer wraps. There's a minimum width set, and if you drag to resize the pane any smaller than that, then things just get cut off, including the "..." button that lets you, e.g., discard or ignore a file. This is true when looking at uncommitted changes, and it's also true of the same pane when looking at an actual commit, which then displays that commit's details, such as committer and message.

Perhaps I'm misremembering, but this minimum width with no wrapping seems like a new thing, and is rather wide on a 13" screen. If it's a regression or unintended change, then I suppose I'm asking for a reversion to previous behavior. But if it's always been this way and I"m misremembering, then I suppose I'm asking that the minimum width not be so wide, and that word wrap would be enabled.

I really wish I could show you the screenshots.
fields.summary: Pending pane has large minimum width, no longer wraps

fields.description:
This is a small bug, but on the flip side, it is probably fast to fix =]

When the preference pane is open to General, all top bar options are displayed. On any other pane, they are collapsed horizontally. For instance, if you open the preference pane and then select the Advanced tab, the Advanced tab itself disappears from the top. 

See attached screenshots for more clarity. Actually, I guess I can't find a way to attach an image to this bug report. That's unfortunate. Please reach out if there is a way to do so that I just can't find. I have screenshots.
fields.summary: Preference pane collapses when not in general

fields.description:
We are having to use the AWS CodeCommit helper git-remote-codecommit since we are required to use MFA with the command line tools.

 

The problem is when using the system version of git it is unable to find the helper module where as in a terminal it's able to find it.

The helper is located at /usr/local/bin which is listed in the /etc/paths file.

 

Not sure what shell environment source tree uses when it executes it's git commands agianst the system git so i'm not sure what path it's using or what one to modify.

 

I was able to work around this by placing a symlink inside of Sourcetree in the git_local/bin directory and switching to use the embedded git. This solution isn't ideal as we'd have to add the symlink back after upgrades.
fields.summary: When using the git-remote-codecommit helper it can't be found using system git

fields.summary: Erro opening

fields.description:
* Right click on a directory that has a large number of files and changes (in File Status view).
 * Select "Log Selected..."
 * Underneath the title bar of the "Log: Multiple Files" window, the names of all of the files are listed _on a single line without text wrap._
 * The result is that the width of the window can be many times wider than the available screen.
 * The width if the window is determined by the length of the text of the list of file names, which may be unlimited.
 * There is with no ability to scroll around this window.
 * Options to close it from the title bar and the button at the bottom right are out of reach.
fields.summary: Log: Multiple Files window is larger than available screen size

fields.description:
SourceTree closes automatically when I click on "Unstaged files" (Header area) and drag.

Here are the steps to reproduce the issue.
 * Open any git repository in SourceTree
 * Choose Show only Pending, Sort by Path alphabetically, Flat list (single column), Fluid Staging
 * Now click on anywhere in the "Unstaged files" header area and drag it.
 * The app will close unexpectedly.
fields.summary: SourceTree closes unexpectedly
Crash report

fields.description:
# commit on iterm2
 # Bring SouceTree foreground

This is occuring since 4.1.2
fields.summary: Crashes when bring app foreground during the repository is lock by commandline

fields.description:
# Copy text on editor
 # Switch to SouceTree and click commit
 # Switch back to editor and paste

Expedted: pasted.

Actual: pasted nothing.
fields.summary: Clipboard is cleared by clicking any commit on History

fields.description:
In SourceTree for Mac (4.0.2), when we've 256 tags in our repo, tag list has complete disappear from the left menu.

If I type *git tag* in console, they appear.

I've deleted from console 1 tag (locally & remote), and with 255 tags, they are appearing again.
fields.summary: Tags are not appearing when exists > 255 tags

fields.description:
I have poured over reports and preferences and can't find option for this behavior so don't know if it's intended or a bug. If it's intended it's still bad it can't be disabled.

Any time I do a commit anything I have on clipboard is wiped clean, the clipboard is literally zeroed out on macOS Big  Sur 11.4 and sourcetree 4.1.2. I can reproduce it 100% of time. I simply copy anything to clipboard, commit to a git repo,  clipboard now blank

this behavior didn't happen on sourcetree 3.x it is new to 4.x It seriously slows down my work flow which sometimes involves copy and pasting commit message into up to 12 repos and now I have to add an extra step of recopying the text from a text document first sincce it's wiped for each and every commit.
fields.summary: Sourcetree clears clipboard on commit

fields.summary: Sourcetree 4.1.2 (238) crashes on launch on macOS 12.0 beta 3 (21A5284e)

fields.description:

 * Create a repository
 * Create a branch called `@test`
 * Try to delete the branch

 It appears to only affect branches starting with an @

fields.description:
This is related to SRCTREE-7702. When I copy one or more paths from the list of files in a particular commit, I often want to perform some kind of operation in the repo directory: editing or zipping up those files or whatever. Probably 90% of the time, what I really want is not the full absolute path to each file, but instead the path to each file relative to the root folder. In fact, I want those paths _exactly as they're displayed in the list of commit files_.

IntelliJ IDEA does a nice job of this, providing a number of options when copying paths, including absolute path, path from source root (which wouldn't really apply to Sourcetree because it's not aware of what a source folder is), and path from content root (project root, I think) or path from repository root, i.e. something like {{src/main/java/.../Foo.java}}, which is what I'd like as an alternative.

fields.description:
There's a long standing infuriating behaviour where the diff view in source tree between two commits refreshes on its own and jumps back to the beginning.  This is particularly infuriating when looking at a large diff - for example between releases or branches of our package. Looking at say 100 files and you're half way down and also scrolling through the individual file diff - you then have to scroll all the way down and find the file again.  Maybe you look at a file or two and within +a minute or two+ it jumps again to the beginning.  It will jump without any input while just reading.

No files are being changed in the mean time behind the scene.

Version 4.1.2 (238) on Mac OS 11.4.
fields.summary: Diff View Jumps back to beginning repeatedely

fields.description:
The panel of the SourceTree UI that shows the diffs of a file has a bar on the left hand side that shows the line numbers of the old version side-by-side with the line numbers of the new version. It turns out that the line numbers of the new version, which are positioned to the right, are being cropped so they can not be read.

I am not sure when this misbehavior started to happen, but it is relatively recent (it might have started after my last two upgrades). I am now using version 4.1.2 (238); just installed it today to check if that issue was solved, but it was not.
fields.summary: Line numbers being cropped on file diff panel

fields.description:
Full Keyboard Access or "tab to navigate" for accessibility doesn't apply to the "Rename Branch" modal text input field.

 

*Expected Behaviour:*

Pressing the _Tab_ key should cycle between all controls, including the text input field.

 

*Actual Behaviour:*

Pressing the _Tab_ key only cycles between the "Cancel" and "OK" buttons.

 

*Additional Notes*

The Full Keyboard Access support is poor in more places, for instance; navigating (i.e. _Tabbing_) never reaches the commit history table or the commit options when the commit panel is open.

fields.description:
h3. Normal behavior:
When you click on a branch in the branches sidebar, the latest commit of that branch is focused, highlighted and scrolled into view in the tree view.

h3. Unexpected behavior:
When a branch is selected in the branches sidebar but that branch's latest commit is *not* selected/focus on the tree view, if you click on the branch to try and locate its latest commit on the tree view, nothing happens. You have to click a different commit or branch, and then click on the original branch again to get the expected behavior.

h3. Reproducibility:
Couldn't tell how to reproduce, but what I described above is the state where this issue happens. It might have to do to checking out different branches.

h3. Expected behavior:
No matter the state of the application GUI, whenever a branch is clicked on the branches sidebar, its latest commit should be selected, focused and scrolled into view.
fields.summary: Clicking a branch in the sidebar not always focuses its latest commit on the tree view.

fields.description:
When SourceTree gets launched right after getting installed, it always starts in Light mode, despite the appearance preference having a default value of "Use macOS system appearance".

Steps to reproduce:
 # Switch macOS to dark mode (by going to System Preferences - General and selecting the Dark appearance)
 # Download SourceTree for the official website and install it.
 # Complete all steps of the Welcome Wizard.
 # Observe the appearance of the SourceTree window.

Expected result: SourceTree starts in Dark mode.

Actual result: SourceTree starts in Light mode.

Environment: SourceTree 4.1.0 (237), macOS Big Sur 11.2.3

Note: Changing the Appearance preference in SourceTree to either Light or Dark, then back to "Use macOS system appearance" fixes the issue.
fields.summary: System Dark Mode preference is not respected upon the very first launch after installation

fields.description:
When the Welcome Wizard offers to configure the global author details for Git and Mercurial, it's not possible to use the Tab key on the keyboard to move the focus between the two text fields.

Steps to reproduce:
 # Download SourceTree for Mac from the official website.
 # Unpack the .zip archive with the app and launch the app.
 # Skip the first two steps of the Welcome Wizard (i.e. do not perform any of the suggested actions)
 # Reach the Preferences step where the Wizard offers to set global author details for Git and Mercurial (see attached screenshot)
 # Type in the user name
 # Press Tab key on a keyboard

Expected result: The focus moves to the email field

Actual result: The whole content of the username field gets selected, the focus doesn't move.

Environment details: SourceTree 4.1.0 (237), macOS Big Sur 11.2.3
fields.summary: Can't use Tab to navigate between text fields on the Preferences step of the Welcome Wizard

fields.description:
Previously, the toolbar was pinned against the left hand side of the window.

It is now pinned to the right, completely breaking the usual flow of things being on the left for left-to-right readers.

The new giant label of the repo I am in is completely superfluous as I can see the tabs and which repo I am in.

Small screen.

!image-2021-04-21-17-16-09-787.png!

Large screen.
!image-2021-04-21-17-17-05-772.png!

Swapping the 2 sections around (toolbar back where it was and the repo name on the right ... or remove it as it serves no purpose ... or have an option to hide this ... or add it to the toolbar modification feature so we can all have it where we want it) would be my suggestion.

Changing people's regular behaviour for no gain is not nice. If there was a fundamental reason to do this, then allow us to adopt to it. Forcing it just means a load of complaints and even more reason to look elsewhere for another tool simply because someone else decided that breaking our behaviour for no gain was a good idea.

I'm not issuing "annotations" (I just read about the whole renaming of git blame to annotation ... and to think you paid the developer for that change ... !), but please put irrelevant cosmetic changes to the bottom of the backlog and concentrate on the productivity issues that exist, like this bug that has messed up my productivity just enough to be annoying.

This change also affects the Properties dialog in such a way that you have to use the expander option to get to any tab on the right hand side of things.

!image-2021-04-21-17-26-07-447.png!
fields.summary: Toolbar pushed right and truncated on small windows.

fields.description:
Gitlab allows to nest groups, e.g.: www.gitlab.com.at/company/subgroup/subsubgroup/project

SourceTree seems to not be able to cope with that (probably because Github does not support such nesting, and Gitlab support in SourceTree builds on top of the Github feature)

When checking out such a project, SourceTree writes into the {{.git/sourcetreeconfig}} file this config:
{code}
remoteProjectLink0.identifier=subsubgroup/project
{code}

When executing "Create Pull Request" in SourceTree, it tries to open https://www.gitlab.com/subsubgroup/project/-/merge_requests/new?... which of course does not exist and show a 404 page.

Even when modifying the {{.git/sourcetreeconfig}} config to point to the correct project path {{company/subgroup/subsubgroup/project}} (and then restarting SourceTree), it does not work, then the "Create Pull Request" action will just do nothing. So SourceTree cannot cope with multiple group levels.

We use a self-hosted version of Gitlab, but I guess the issue should affect gitlab.com too.
fields.summary: "Create Pull Request" does not work with a Gitlab project nested inside multiple levels of groups
